htmlEmbed:
Biden officials worry pandemic exhaustion could lead to bad covid winterDan Diamond10/26/2022

Their focus is on getting reformulated coronavirus vaccine booster shots to seniors and the immunocompromised to avert thousands of preventable deaths.

HealthRead

data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-apitype="text" data-contentid="I763Z5PC65DLLDRBH55LJEZGIM" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-hoAgRD wpds-c-hoAgRD-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">Amid projections that tens of thousands of Americans could die needlessly this winter if they dont get free <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/coronavirus/?itid=lk_inline_manual_2" target="_blank" class="contextual_link">coronavirus</a> vaccine shots or treatments, White House Chief of Staff Ron Klain summoned health officials to a meeting last week with an urgent question: What can we do to prevent this?</p></div></div><div></div><div class="wpds-c-PJLV article-body" data-qa="article-body"></div><div class="wpds-c-PJLV article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-apitype="text" data-contentid="7JHJPN3FWBAYTF42FF2WYZA5KI" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-hoAgRD wpds-c-hoAgRD-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">What emerged from that session was a fall playbook to combat the virus that was timed to President Biden receiving an updated coronavirus vaccination shot (his fifth dose overall) on Tuesday, according to four people who spoke on the condition of anonymity because they were not authorized to comment. The steps include enlisting Walgreens, DoorDash and Uber to provide free delivery of antiviral prescriptions, and focusing on persuading vulnerable Americans, including seniors, to get vaccinations and booster shots.</p></div><div class="wpds-c-PJLV article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-apitype="text" data-contentid="6SDY7O5IR5HX7BI4GN4C5BLQCI" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-hoAgRD wpds-c-hoAgRD-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">As a country  we have a choice to make, Biden said, before rolling up his left shirt sleeve to get the new shot. If we repeat the mistakes of past winters, he warned, we will see more infections, more hospitalizations, more loved ones getting sick, even dying, from the virus. Or can we have a much better winter, if we use all, all the tools we have available to us now, including reformulated booster shots and antiviral pills, such as Paxlovid.</p></div><div class="wpds-c-PJLV wpds-c-PJLV-bHCGeL-isStandardLayoutAd-true article-body" data-qa="article-body"><div class="cb dn db-ns" data-qa="article-body-ad" data-testid="article-body-ad-desktop"><div data-qa="article-body-ad" data-testid="article-body-ad-mobile"><div aria-hidden="true" class="hide-for-print relative flex justify-center content-box items-center b bh mb-md mt-sm pt-sm pb-sm article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-apitype="text" data-contentid="PAXAO2FHO5GNVGI2ANC2WVLP3U" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-hoAgRD wpds-c-hoAgRD-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">The administration also is encouraging businesses to set up vaccination clinics, offer paid time off for workers to get shots, and improve their indoor air quality  moves that officials and outside experts acknowledge recycle prior tactics rather than representing a new strategy and may not be enough to forestall many deaths.</p></div><div class="wpds-c-PJLV article-body" data-qa="article-body"></div><div class="wpds-c-PJLV article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-apitype="text" data-contentid="3SZVBJEF7FAA5OWAKF52RJHUXM" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-hoAgRD wpds-c-hoAgRD-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">Entering the nations third coronavirus winter, the United States appears to be in a far better position than it was during the past two: Treatments and booster shots are widely available, and most Americans have some protection against the viruss worst consequences, as a result of<b> </b>vaccinations, prior infections or both. As schools and businesses have reopened, a <a href="https://www.cnn.com/2022/10/12/politics/cnn-poll-biden-approval/index.html" target=_blank>CNN poll</a> released this month found that 55 percent of respondents approve of Bidens coronavirus response, versus just 36 percent who approve of his handling of the economy.</p></div><div class="wpds-c-PJLV article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-apitype="text" data-contentid="FEQLKDZPGJCOLAZHKJAYQFTVVY" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-hoAgRD wpds-c-hoAgRD-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">But health officials privately worry about limited funds, worn-out front-line health workers and the dwindling receptivity of many Americans to covid precautions. Polls show that many people are apathetic or confused about the need to get further vaccinations, opposed to resuming <a href="https://www.monmouth.edu/polling-institute/reports/monmouthpoll_us_101122/" target="_blank">mask mandates</a> and eager to put the pandemic behind them.</p></div><div class="wpds-c-PJLV article-body" data-qa="article-body"><div class="PJLV PJLV-iPJLV-css hide-for-print" data-qa="article-image"><div style="min-height:358px"></div></div></div><div class="wpds-c-PJLV article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-apitype="text" data-contentid="W7DHL3NNHJGQBMVUAXWQ3LBPOE" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-hoAgRD wpds-c-hoAgRD-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">Approval of agencies like the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has <a href="https://www.pewresearch.org/science/2022/10/05/lack-of-preparedness-among-top-reactions-americans-have-to-public-health-officials-covid-19-response/" target="_blank">fallen</a> by about one-third since the start of the pandemic, according to a recent Pew Research poll, with the most significant criticism from Republicans who are disproportionately likely to be unvaccinated. Just 6 percent of eligible Americans have received an <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/health/2022/10/07/covid-booster-winter-surge/?itid=lk_inline_manual_12" target="_blank">updated booster shot</a>, according to federal data.</p></div><div class="wpds-c-PJLV wpds-c-PJLV-bHCGeL-isStandardLayoutAd-true article-body" data-qa="article-body"><div class="cb dn db-ns" data-qa="article-body-ad" data-testid="article-body-ad-desktop"><div aria-hidden="true" class="hide-for-print relative flex justify-center content-box items-center b bh mb-md mt-none pt-lg pb-lg" style="min-height:250px"><div class="center absolute w-100 border-box"><div class="dib gray-dark pl-xs pr-xs font-sans-serif light font-xxxxs lh-md" style="--primary-border-color:var(--wpds-colors-alpha25)"></div></div><div gray-dark pl-xs pr-xs font-sans-serif light font-xxxxs lh-md" style="--primary-border-color:var(--wpds-colors-alpha25)"></div></div><div data-testid="placeholder-box" class="w-100 h-100 absolute flex flex-column justify-center border-box bg-offwhite" style="width:300px;height:250px"><div class="flex flex-column justify-center font-sans-serif center font-xxs light gray-dark lh-md"></div></div></div></div></div><div class="wpds-c-PJLV article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-apitype="text" data-contentid="FLUCRCHONZFBHKAAGBLD4SMQOU" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-hoAgRD wpds-c-hoAgRD-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">Nearly three years into a seemingly unending virus fight, local and national officials are weary, too, and said in interviews that theyve effectively exhausted tactics to reach vaccine<b> </b>holdouts and are pivoting to protect the most vulnerable Americans, such as seniors and people with immune-system conditions. Meanwhile, resurgent flu and other respiratory viruses are <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/health/2022/10/21/rsv-children-hospital-capacity/?itid=lk_inline_manual_15" target=_blank>crowding hospitals</a>, heaping more pressure on<b> </b>employees coping with persistent workforce shortages.</p></div><div class="wpds-c-PJLV article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p><span class="wpds-c-sFUaP wpds-c-sFUaP-iwFqEg-variant-interstitial wpds-c-sFUaP-iPJLV-css overrideStyles hide-for-print"><a data-qa="interstitial-link" data-testid="interstitial-link" href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/health/2022/10/21/rsv-children-hospital-capacity/?itid=lk_interstitial_manual_16">RSV, other viruses making it hard to find a bed in childrens hospitals</a></span></p></div><div class="wpds-c-PJLV article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-apitype="text" data-contentid="65BSO7HHOFBQJJ2YOP7UROTBFE" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-hoAgRD wpds-c-hoAgRD-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">One of the top officials in Klains meeting  CDC Director Rochelle Walensky, who joined remotely from Germany  would soon <a href="https://www.cdc.gov/media/releases/2022/s1022-covid-director.html" target=_blank>test positive</a>, scarcely a month after receiving an updated booster shot, underscoring the limits of vaccines to prevent infections from the evolving virus, although studies show they protect against severe covid infections and death.</p></div><div class="wpds-c-PJLV article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-apitype="text" data-contentid="HIDHRMLJEJHQBOU6OAIEWY427M" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-hoAgRD wpds-c-hoAgRD-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">Were in a very challenging phase, to be very honest. I know most folks dont want to hear that, said Syra Madad, an epidemiologist who helps oversee pandemic response for NYC Health and Hospitals, the nations largest municipal health-care system. Barely anybody is masking. We have very low vaccination rates for the updated boosters, as well as generally waning immunity. And to top it all off, we have these highly immune-evasive subvariants that are circulating.</p></div><div class="wpds-c-PJLV wpds-c-PJLV-bHCGeL-isStandardLayoutAd-true article-body" data-qa="article-body"><div class="cb dn db-ns" data-qa="article-body-ad" data-testid="article-body-ad-desktop"><div aria-hidden="true" class="hide-for-print relative flex justify-center content-box class="wpds-c-PJLV wpds-c-PJLV-bHCGeL-isStandardLayoutAd-true article-body" data-qa="article-body"><div class="cb db dn-ns" data-qa="article-body-ad" data-testid="article-body-ad-mobile"><div font-xxxxs lh-md" style="--primary-border-color:var(--wpds-colors-alpha25)"></div></div><div data-testid="placeholder-box" class="w-100 h-100 absolute flex flex-column justify-center border-box bg-offwhite" style="width:300px;height:250px"><div class="flex flex-column justify-center font-sans-serif center font-xxs light gray-dark lh-md"></div></div></div></div></div><div class="wpds-c-PJLV article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-apitype="text" data-contentid="2W6QOTDIQZEBFCUVPACBLP3L7I" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-hoAgRD wpds-c-hoAgRD-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">Madad credited administration officials efforts to continue warning about the virus  but said nearly two years of pandemic response had taken its toll on them, as well as on the American public.</p></div><div class="wpds-c-PJLV article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-apitype="text" data-contentid="L3JXRFKCKFFJNKA4A2ZBPXQ4BE" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-hoAgRD wpds-c-hoAgRD-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">They are working off of fumes, she said.</p></div><div class="wpds-c-PJLV article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-apitype="text" data-contentid="TZMJDY2T7RE7NFX6JNOOPJLOGA" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-hoAgRD wpds-c-hoAgRD-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">The biggest unknown heading into the winter is a shape-shifting virus that is becoming more adept at evading immunity.<b> </b>At this point a year ago, the virus variant that became omicron had not been identified<b> </b> but by Christmas 2021, it had caused <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/health/2021/12/30/hospitals-staffing-shortages-omicron/?itid=lk_inline_manual_23" target="_blank">tens of millions of infections</a>, and by January 2022, it led to some of the highest death rates of the pandemic. Scientists say omicron variant descendants such as B.Q.1.1 and XBB <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/health/2022/10/18/covid-variants-xbb-bq1-bq11/?itid=lk_inline_manual_23" target="_blank">could soon render useless treatments such as Evusheld,</a> a therapy used to prevent illness in immunocompromised people.</p></div><div class="wpds-c-PJLV article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p><span class="wpds-c-sFUaP wpds-c-sFUaP-iwFqEg-variant-interstitial wpds-c-sFUaP-iPJLV-css overrideStyles hide-for-print"><a data-qa="interstitial-link" data-testid="interstitial-link" href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/health/2022/10/18/covid-variants-xbb-bq1-bq11/?itid=lk_interstitial_manual_24">A variant swarm could fuel a winter surge</a></span></p></div><div class="wpds-c-PJLV article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-apitype="text" data-contentid="UCBZUQDYRVEJXAFW3V4D4BKUZY" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-hoAgRD wpds-c-hoAgRD-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">If we hit a bad outcome [again], I think were going to be shocked again into action, while just realizing how much we let our guard down, said J. Stephen Morrison, who oversees global health policy at the Center for Strategic and International Studies. He also pointed to struggles to deal with other recent outbreaks, such as <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/health/2022/08/17/monkeypox-biden-vaccine-testing-mistakes/?itid=lk_inline_manual_25" target="_blank">monkeypox cases</a> in the United States and Europe, and Ebola cases in Uganda, saying sluggish efforts to conduct contact tracing and implement protections show persistent cracks in the global health response. Its just depressing that three years into this pandemic, were in such a weak position  so much weaker than we should have been and so much weaker than we were when we started, Morrison said.</p></div><div class="wpds-c-PJLV wpds-c-PJLV-bHCGeL-isStandardLayoutAd-true article-body" data-qa="article-body"><div class="cb dn db-ns" data-qa="article-body-ad" overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">Several of Bidens former advisers said the president could do more to<b> </b>deliver on his campaign pledge to improve the nations public health class="wpds-c-hoAgRD wpds-c-hoAgRD-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">We need to assess the opportunities squandered or missed in the Covid pandemic and seize them now, four former Biden coronavirus advisers wrote in an <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2022/10/19/opinion/covid-pandemic-failures.html" target=_blank>op-ed</a> in the New York Times last week. The column blamed Congress for not authorizing billions of dollars for such public health efforts and the administration for failing to adopt relatively low-cost interventions, such as standardizing how wastewater is sampled to detect covid and other viruses, or issuing national air quality standards that could lead to safer restaurants, businesses and schools.</p></div><div class="wpds-c-PJLV article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-apitype="text" data-contentid="HI6JR3QGIBEZVFUBZUCYQ6MD4M" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-hoAgRD wpds-c-hoAgRD-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">We cant let this moment pass with so few structural, substantive, institutional improvements. It would be a terrible tragedy, said Ezekiel Emanuel, a University of Pennsylvania bioethicist and one of the co-authors. Because a lot of people will die the next time around. We dont know when exactly thats going to be, but its going to be.</p></div><div class="wpds-c-PJLV article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-apitype="text" data-contentid="PKQ7XOQPHBAWPOQF7XMZLNTBVE" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-hoAgRD wpds-c-hoAgRD-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">Public health experts acknowledge that the messaging climate is difficult, partly because of public exhaustion with covid, but also because Democrats have sought to amplify other messages, such as <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/abortion/?itid=lk_inline_manual_53" target="_blank" class="contextual_link">abortion</a> access, heading into next months midterm elections.</p></div><div class="wpds-c-PJLV article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-apitype="text" data-contentid="CYCKUQHN25B2JO6PE5UGVJ3HGQ" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-hoAgRD wpds-c-hoAgRD-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">In interviews, federal and state officials lamented, for instance, how they failed to proactively explain a planned vote by CDC advisers last week to add coronavirus vaccinations to the agencys recommended immunization schedules for children, calling it a missed opportunity. Conservatives and Fox News personalities twisted the advisory panels vote into <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/health/2022/10/19/covid-vaccines-children-cdc-disinformation/?itid=lk_inline_manual_54" target=_blank>false claims</a> that schools would immediately mandate that children receive the shots.</p></div><div class="wpds-c-PJLV article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-apitype="text" data-contentid="X6SAJLTYEBE6PPGDMNAV7IBM34" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-hoAgRD wpds-c-hoAgRD-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">Resneck, the AMAs president, said misinformation about covid and vaccines is being driven by a small number of people whose messages are amplified by social media. Jeff Zients and Natalie Quillian, who led Bidens coronavirus response before stepping down this spring, have returned to the White House to oversee potential personnel changes after the midterms, <a href="https://www.axios.com/2022/09/23/scoop-white-house-prepares-for-post-midterm-turnover" target=_blank>Axios first reported</a>.</p></div><div class="wpds-c-PJLV article-body" prompted <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2022/01/31/becerra-hhs-pandemic-response-leadership/?itid=lk_inline_manual_59" target="_blank">internal discussions</a> about replacing the health secretary early this year.<b> </b>Administration officials also <a href="https://www.politico.com/news/2022/08/12/becerra-monkeypox-covid-response-00051422" target="_blank">faulted</a> Becerras team this summer for <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/health/2022/08/17/monkeypox-biden-vaccine-testing-mistakes/?itid=lk_inline_manual_59" target="_blank">stumbles on monkeypox</a>, which data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-apitype="text" data-contentid="UEFCJQ3MP5GGBF672GCOGJYSJA" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-hoAgRD wpds-c-hoAgRD-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">This is untrue. He would say hes not doing that today, tomorrow or next year, Lovenheim said in a statement. He looks forward to negotiating prescription drug costs, protecting reproductive rights, doubling down to strengthen mental and behavioral health, public health preparedness and more.</p></div><div class="wpds-c-PJLV article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-apitype="text" data-contentid="CZYRVFSI3RFP5HYVPO45FRC4DA" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-hoAgRD wpds-c-hoAgRD-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">Administration officials have also discussed whether Walensky, who has faced criticism for the CDCs sometimes-confusing messages on the pandemic, would leave after the midterms, according to three people with knowledge of those deliberations who spoke on the condition of anonymity to discuss sensitive conversations. Unlike other positions, such as HHS secretary, the role of CDC director does not require Senate confirmation, making it easier for the administration to execute a job change.</p></div><div class="wpds-c-PJLV article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-apitype="text" data-contentid="M5R7Q275VNFVBI5DP6IT7XBU2U" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-hoAgRD wpds-c-hoAgRD-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">A spokesperson for Walensky referred The Washington Post to her <a href="https://transcripts.cnn.com/show/wtcw/date/2022-10-09/segment/01" target=_blank>interview this month</a> with CNNs Chris Wallace, in which the director touted her <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/health/2022/08/17/walensky-revamp-cdc-culture-covid/?itid=lk_inline_manual_63" target=_blank>agency-reform plan</a>, announced in August, and promised to stay on to oversee it. My work is not done, Walensky said.</p></div></div><div class="wpds-c-jkoBlc wpds-c-jkoBlc-leHWbT-removeAllStyles-true"><div class="wpds-c-gMxubY"><div data-orientation="horizontal" role="separator" class="wpds-c-dbVHzF wpds-c-dbVHzF-hDkAcj-variant-default wpds-c-dbVHzF-idetizB-css"></div><div class="wpds-c-jjHkyS wpds-c-jjHkyS-iVhOHg-css hide-for-print"><div data-qa="content" class="wpds-c-CrkDw wpds-c-CrkDw-iPJLV-css"><h3 data-qa="linkbox-headline" class="wpds-c-jtAZFm">Coronavirus: What you need to know</h3><p class="wpds-c-eynqHn"><b>Covid isolation guidelines: </b><a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/health/2024/03/01/new-cdc-covid-isolation-guidelines/" target=_blank>Americans who test positive for the coronavirus no longer need to routinely stay home</a> from work and school for five days under new guidance<b> </b>planned<b> </b>by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. The change has <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/health/2024/02/17/cdc-covid-isolation-vulnerable-sick-leave/" target=_blank>raised concerns<b> </b>among medically vulnerable people</a>.</p><p class="wpds-c-eynqHn"><b>New coronavirus variant:</b> The <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/health/2024/05/14/covid-variant-flirt-symptoms-vaccine/" target=_blank>CDC said it is monitoring a variant called KP.2</a> and does not see evidence it causes more severe illness than other strains.  It also identified a second emergent variant, KP.1.1. But it is KP.2 that is leading the pack. Both new variants belong to a group of coronavirus variants dubbed FLiRT by scientists.</p><p class="wpds-c-eynqHn"><b>Latest coronavirus booster:</b> The CDC recommends that anyone 6 months or older <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/health/2023/09/12/covid-booster-shots-2023-cdc/" target=_blank>gets an updated coronavirus shot</a>, but the <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/health/2023/09/22/covid-vaccine-insurance-coverage-denials/" target=_blank>vaccine rollout has seen some hiccups</a>, <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/health/2023/10/02/kids-covid-vaccine-shortage/" target=_blank>especially for children</a>. Heres <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/health/2023/09/11/new-covid-booster/" target=_blank>what you need to know about the latest coronavirus vaccines</a>, including when you should get it.</p></div><div class="wpds-c-eZxssT"></div></div><div data-orientation="horizontal" role="separator" class="wpds-c-dbVHzF wpds-c-dbVHzF-hDkAcj-variant-default (Tom Brenner for The Washington Post)","height":3334,"image_type":"photograph","subtype":"StaffPhoto","taxonomy":{},"type":"image","url":"https://arc-anglerfish-washpost-prod-washpost.s3.amazonaws.com/public/7DM56ZSG6ZWWKMPW2SEQL2UXIQ.JPG","width":5000,"originalIdx":0},{"_id":"I763Z5PC65DLLDRBH55LJEZGIM","additional_properties":{},"content":"Amid projections that tens of thousands of Americans could die needlessly this winter if they dont get free \u003ca href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/coronavirus/\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"contextual_link\"\u003ecoronavirus\u003c/a\u003e vaccine shots or treatments, White House Chief of Staff Ron Klain summoned health officials to a meeting last week with an urgent question: What can we do to prevent this?","type":"text","originalIdx":1},{"_id":"7JHJPN3FWBAYTF42FF2WYZA5KI","additional_properties":{},"content":"What emerged from that session was a fall playbook to combat the virus that was timed to President Biden receiving an updated coronavirus vaccination shot (his fifth dose overall) on Tuesday, according to four people who spoke on the condition of anonymity because they were not authorized to comment. The steps include enlisting Walgreens, DoorDash and Uber to provide free delivery of antiviral prescriptions, and focusing on persuading vulnerable Americans, including seniors, to get vaccinations and booster shots.","type":"text","originalIdx":2},{"_id":"6SDY7O5IR5HX7BI4GN4C5BLQCI","additional_properties":{},"content":"As a country  we have a choice to make, Biden said, before rolling up his left shirt sleeve to get the new shot. If we repeat the mistakes of past winters, he warned, we will see more infections, more hospitalizations, more loved ones getting sick, even dying, from the virus. Or can we have a much better winter, if we use all, all the tools we have available to us now, including reformulated booster shots and antiviral pills, such as Paxlovid.","type":"text","originalIdx":3},{"_id":"PAXAO2FHO5GNVGI2ANC2WVLP3U","additional_properties":{},"content":"The administration also is encouraging businesses to set up vaccination clinics, offer paid time off for workers to get shots, and improve their indoor air quality  moves that officials and outside experts acknowledge recycle prior tactics rather than representing a new strategy and may not be enough to forestall many deaths.","type":"text","originalIdx":4},{"_id":"3SZVBJEF7FAA5OWAKF52RJHUXM","additional_properties":{},"content":"Entering the nations third coronavirus winter, the United States appears to be in a far better position than it was during the past two: Treatments and booster shots are widely available, and most Americans have some protection against the viruss worst consequences, as a result of\u003cb\u003e \u003c/b\u003evaccinations, prior infections or both. As schools and businesses have reopened, a \u003ca href=\"https://www.cnn.com/2022/10/12/politics/cnn-poll-biden-approval/index.html\" target=_blank\u003eCNN poll\u003c/a\u003e released this month found that 55 percent of respondents approve of Bidens coronavirus response, versus just 36 percent who approve of his handling of the economy.","type":"text","originalIdx":5},{"_id":"FEQLKDZPGJCOLAZHKJAYQFTVVY","additional_properties":{},"content":"But health officials privately worry about limited funds, worn-out front-line health workers and the dwindling receptivity of many Americans to covid precautions. Polls show that many people are apathetic or confused about the need to get further vaccinations, opposed to resuming \u003ca href=\"https://www.monmouth.edu/polling-institute/reports/monmouthpoll_us_101122/\" target=\"_blank\"\u003emask mandates\u003c/a\u003e and eager to put the pandemic behind them.","type":"text","originalIdx":6},{"_id":"JTU4PTVTMF4444ZGNCYULOZEPI","additional_properties":{"media_size":"medium"},"credits":{"by":[{"name":"Kevin Lamarque"}]},"credits_caption_display":"A woman works at a coffee shop in D.C.'s Georgetown neighborhood. Heading into the third covid winter, few Americans are wearing masks in public spaces. (Kevin Lamarque/Reuters)","height":2254,"subtype":"WireImage","taxonomy":{},"type":"image","url":"https://arc-anglerfish-washpost-prod-washpost.s3.amazonaws.com/public/JTU4PTVTMF4444ZGNCYULOZEPI.JPG","width":3500,"originalIdx":7},{"_id":"W7DHL3NNHJGQBMVUAXWQ3LBPOE","additional_properties":{},"content":"Approval of agencies like the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has \u003ca href=\"https://www.pewresearch.org/science/2022/10/05/lack-of-preparedness-among-top-reactions-americans-have-to-public-health-officials-covid-19-response/\" target=\"_blank\"\u003efallen\u003c/a\u003e by about one-third since the start of the pandemic, according to a recent Pew Research poll, with the most significant criticism from Republicans who are disproportionately likely to be unvaccinated. Just 6 percent of eligible Americans have received an \u003ca href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/health/2022/10/07/covid-booster-winter-surge/\" target=\"_blank\"\u003eupdated booster shot\u003c/a\u003e, according to federal data.","type":"text","originalIdx":8},{"_id":"FLUCRCHONZFBHKAAGBLD4SMQOU","additional_properties":{},"content":"Nearly three years into a seemingly unending virus fight, local and national officials are weary, too, and said in interviews that theyve effectively exhausted tactics to reach vaccine\u003cb\u003e \u003c/b\u003eholdouts and are pivoting to protect the most vulnerable Americans, such as seniors and people with immune-system conditions. Meanwhile, resurgent flu and other respiratory viruses are \u003ca href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/health/2022/10/21/rsv-children-hospital-capacity/\" target=_blank\u003ecrowding hospitals\u003c/a\u003e, heaping more pressure on\u003cb\u003e \u003c/b\u003eemployees coping with persistent workforce shortages.","type":"text","originalIdx":9},{"_id":"G5ZIGV2TERFFHIIW2PSDVMKKOE","additional_properties":{},"content":"RSV, other viruses making it hard to find a bed in childrens hospitals","type":"interstitial_link","url":"https://www.washingtonpost.com/health/2022/10/21/rsv-children-hospital-capacity/","originalIdx":10},{"_id":"65BSO7HHOFBQJJ2YOP7UROTBFE","additional_properties":{},"content":"One of the top officials in Klains meeting  CDC Director Rochelle Walensky, who joined remotely from Germany  would soon \u003ca href=\"https://www.cdc.gov/media/releases/2022/s1022-covid-director.html\" target=_blank\u003etest positive\u003c/a\u003e, scarcely a month after receiving an updated booster shot, underscoring the limits of vaccines to prevent infections from the evolving virus, although studies show they protect against severe covid infections and death.","type":"text","originalIdx":11},{"_id":"HIDHRMLJEJHQBOU6OAIEWY427M","additional_properties":{},"content":"Were in a very challenging phase, to be very honest. I know most folks dont want to hear that, said Syra Madad, an epidemiologist who helps oversee pandemic response for NYC Health and Hospitals, the nations largest municipal health-care system. Barely anybody is masking. We have very low vaccination rates for the updated boosters, as well as generally waning immunity. And to top it all off, we have these highly immune-evasive subvariants that are circulating.","type":"text","originalIdx":12},{"_id":"2W6QOTDIQZEBFCUVPACBLP3L7I","additional_properties":{},"content":"Madad credited administration officials efforts to continue warning about the virus  but said nearly two years of pandemic response had taken its toll on them, as well as on the American public.","type":"text","originalIdx":13},{"_id":"L3JXRFKCKFFJNKA4A2ZBPXQ4BE","additional_properties":{},"content":"They are working off of fumes, she said.","type":"text","originalIdx":14},{"_id":"TZMJDY2T7RE7NFX6JNOOPJLOGA","additional_properties":{},"content":"The biggest unknown heading into the winter is a shape-shifting virus that is becoming more adept at evading immunity.\u003cb\u003e \u003c/b\u003eAt this point a year ago, the virus variant that became omicron had not been identified\u003cb\u003e \u003c/b\u003e but by Christmas 2021, it had caused \u003ca href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/health/2021/12/30/hospitals-staffing-shortages-omicron/\" target=\"_blank\"\u003etens of millions of infections\u003c/a\u003e, and by January 2022, it led to some of the highest death rates of the pandemic. Scientists say omicron variant descendants such as B.Q.1.1 and XBB \u003ca href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/health/2022/10/18/covid-variants-xbb-bq1-bq11/\" target=\"_blank\"\u003ecould soon render useless treatments such as Evusheld,\u003c/a\u003e a therapy used to prevent illness in immunocompromised people.","type":"text","originalIdx":15},{"_id":"RBPUS3BBM5CWVI4OCAFPIG2IEY","additional_properties":{},"content":"A variant swarm could fuel a winter surge","type":"interstitial_link","url":"https://www.washingtonpost.com/health/2022/10/18/covid-variants-xbb-bq1-bq11/","originalIdx":16},{"_id":"UCBZUQDYRVEJXAFW3V4D4BKUZY","additional_properties":{},"content":"If we hit a bad outcome [again], I think were going to be shocked again into action, while just realizing how much we let our guard down, said J. Stephen Morrison, who oversees global health policy at the Center for Strategic and International Studies. He also pointed to struggles to deal with other recent outbreaks, such as \u003ca href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/health/2022/08/17/monkeypox-biden-vaccine-testing-mistakes/\" target=\"_blank\"\u003emonkeypox cases\u003c/a\u003e in the United States and Europe, and Ebola cases in Uganda, saying sluggish efforts to conduct contact tracing and implement protections show persistent cracks in the global health response. Its just depressing that three years into this pandemic, were in such a weak position  so much weaker than we should have been and so much weaker than we were when we started, Morrison said.","type":"text","originalIdx":17},{"_id":"5EUQMGFGVRHZVMZDBU2ITCUI2E","additional_properties":{},"content":"The path could get tougher next year. Republicans are expected to win one or both chambers of Congress, further clouding\u003cb\u003e \u003c/b\u003ethe prospects of a long-stalled  virus funding package of more than $20 billion sought by the White House. The Biden administration also plans to phase out government purchases of vaccines and other treatments in 2023, pushing the cost to patients and insurers and potentially hindering uptake.","type":"text","originalIdx":18},{"_id":"2ZQWD3DA3FEMXJSQXB3BABOZHE","additional_properties":{},"content":"About 360 deaths per day\u003cb\u003e \u003c/b\u003eare still linked to covid, and over the course of the winter, the administration is bracing for 30,000 to 70,000 additional casualties despite public health experts insistence that most of those deaths can be avoided with vaccinations and antiviral treatments.","type":"text","originalIdx":19},{"_id":"3T54QFGZT5DKPHUP3MI674U4SE","additional_properties":{},"content":"This year, nearly every death is preventable. Let me say it again: Nearly every death is preventable, Biden said Tuesday.","type":"text","originalIdx":20},{"_id":"3HFSM2UZXNFKDBOC6OYKYNREVY","additional_properties":{},"content":"Regional disparities have also emerged, with \u003ca href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2022/10/03/pandemic-biden-trump-deaths/?itid=lk_inline_manual_74\"\u003epersistent gaps\u003c/a\u003e in vaccinations between Democrats and Republicans and higher death rates as a result.","type":"text","originalIdx":21},{"_id":"4H5O7T7UAVCHZG6N5HAUBTSFZU","additional_properties":{},"content":"I worry about future responses because of how political weve made this thing, said Alex Jahangir, a Vanderbilt Health trauma surgeon who led Nashvilles coronavirus task force for two years. Were at a place where most people know what to do to keep themselves from being super sick and dying. The problem  especially in the Southeast  is, we choose not to do it.","type":"text","originalIdx":22},{"_id":"5VYL4PV6FNB67PAY6HQUH77DPM","additional_properties":{},"content":"Seeking to ramp up awareness of those tools, Health and Human Services Secretary Xavier Becerra is attending vaccination events in Texas and California this week, and his agency is launching ads targeting rural, Black and Latino populations.","type":"text","originalIdx":23},{"_id":"QMR45RLVPBCRRNSCC363N26L2U","raw_oembed":{"_id":"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=W-vp45ItkkA","additional_properties":{"_id":1666903713036,"comments":[]},"author_name":"U.S. Department of Health and Human Services","author_url":"https://www.youtube.com/c/HHS","height":113,"html":"\u003ciframe width=\"200\" height=\"113\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/W-vp45ItkkA?feature=oembed\" frameborder=\"0\" allow=\"accelerometer; autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture\" allowfullscreen title=\"Just In Time: Updated COVID-19 Vaccines - :30\"\u003e\u003c/iframe\u003e","provider_name":"YouTube","provider_url":"https://www.youtube.com/","thumbnail_height":360,"thumbnail_url":"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/W-vp45ItkkA/hqdefault.jpg","thumbnail_width":480,"title":"Just In Time: Updated COVID-19 Vaccines - :30","type":"youtube","version":"1.0","width":200},"referent":{"id":"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=W-vp45ItkkA"},"subtype":"youtube","type":"oembed_response","originalIdx":24},{"_id":"54XJI5XL7ZHSLH6RW2QFILYMXM","additional_properties":{},"content":"AARP, an advocacy group for seniors, held \u003ca href=\"https://www.facebook.com/AARPPrograms/videos/covid-vaccines-treatments-and-flu-season/4006978292759289/\" target=_blank\u003ea telephone town hall\u003c/a\u003e last week during which White House coronavirus coordinator Ashish Jha fielded questions, such as how to gather safely for Thanksgiving, from more than 35,000 attendees. AARP is also set to send its monthly magazine to its nearly 38 million members with a cover story on how seniors can stay healthy this winter by accessing coronavirus treatments, tests and vaccines.","type":"text","originalIdx":25},{"_id":"NM7L6MMUBVDSXCLZBBSAIRSGLQ","additional_properties":{},"content":"Im both worried and optimistic about the winter, said Debra Whitman, AARPs chief public policy officer, saying her organization is focused on boosting vaccination rates among older adults. She pointed to high-risk settings such as nursing homes, where just 43 percent of employees and 55 percent of residents were up-to-date on their vaccinations, according to AARPs \u003ca href=\"https://www.aarp.org/ppi/issues/caregiving/info-2020/nursing-home-covid-dashboard.html\" target=\"_blank\"\u003elatest scorecard\u003c/a\u003e. These are preventable deaths, in places where far too many people have died already, she said.","type":"text","originalIdx":26},{"_id":"54XJI5XL7ZHSLH6RW2QFILYMXM","additional_properties":{},"content":"The Biden administration has also enlisted health-care providers, through groups such as the American Medical Association and the American Association of Nurse Practitioners, to encourage their patients to get vaccinated,\u003cb\u003e \u003c/b\u003epart of a broader push toward shots in doctors offices and clinics, rather than in mass vaccination sites","type":"text","originalIdx":27},{"_id":"2ID6AHHJHBE3BN2532YEJXPR6E","additional_properties":{},"content":"We dont have a crystal ball  but there are some concerning signs about upticks [in cases] and some new variants, said AMA President Jack Resneck Jr., who joined about a dozen clinical leaders at the White House last week. And so the American Medical Association and physicians broadly are really encouraging Americans to get their updated boosters because we really want to reduce both hospitalizations and deaths this winter.","type":"text","originalIdx":28},{"_id":"3GQFH7QUDBDFDCDM2RS36RFKCQ","additional_properties":{},"content":"Some outside experts have said the administrations efforts are coming too late, pointing to moments when Biden or his deputies seemed to put the virus behind them  with the president \u003ca href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/health/2022/09/18/biden-covid-pandemic-over/\"\u003edeclaring\u003c/a\u003e on television last month that the pandemic is over, for instance.","type":"text","originalIdx":29},{"_id":"RUEHEDECQ5B6TJZKD26VHL4GTI","additional_properties":{},"content":"Ceclia Tomori, director of global public health and community health at Johns Hopkins School of Nursing, said Biden officials had increasingly turned\u003cb\u003e \u003c/b\u003etheir pandemic strategy into individual choices, rather than taking responsibility for the nations collective response.","type":"text","originalIdx":30},{"_id":"U5RBICMM6BCWVM37ZKJQCQ6R2Q","additional_properties":{},"content":"When you make a rhetorical choice like the pandemic of the unvaccinated, youre really shifting blame, Tomori said. She argued that the phrase, which was first uttered by Walensky and repeated by Biden and other officials, needlessly alienated Americans who had yet to get vaccinated. Republicans also mocked the statement after the virus evolved to the point that vaccines failed to prevent  infections among vaccinated people.","type":"text","originalIdx":31},{"_id":"UBFFTAAKONBJDHZRNEF6MRBFKM","additional_properties":{},"content":"Several of Bidens former advisers said the president could do more to\u003cb\u003e \u003c/b\u003edeliver on his campaign pledge to improve the nations public health infrastructure.","type":"text","originalIdx":32},{"_id":"3PQZG5J3N5DMLMRVVVRTYMI3SY","additional_properties":{},"content":"We need to assess the opportunities squandered or missed in the Covid pandemic and seize them now, four former Biden coronavirus advisers wrote in an \u003ca href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2022/10/19/opinion/covid-pandemic-failures.html\" target=_blank\u003eop-ed\u003c/a\u003e in the New York Times last week. The column blamed Congress for not authorizing billions of dollars for such public health efforts and the administration for failing to adopt relatively low-cost interventions, such as standardizing how wastewater is sampled to detect covid and other viruses, or issuing national air quality standards that could lead to safer restaurants, businesses and schools.","type":"text","originalIdx":33},{"_id":"HI6JR3QGIBEZVFUBZUCYQ6MD4M","additional_properties":{},"content":"We cant let this moment pass with so few structural, substantive, institutional improvements. It would be a terrible tragedy, said Ezekiel Emanuel, a University of Pennsylvania bioethicist and one of the co-authors. Because a lot of people will die the next time around. We dont know when exactly thats going to be, but its going to be.","type":"text","originalIdx":34},{"_id":"PKQ7XOQPHBAWPOQF7XMZLNTBVE","additional_properties":{},"content":"Public health experts acknowledge that the messaging climate is difficult, partly because of public exhaustion with covid, but also because Democrats have sought to amplify other messages, such as \u003ca href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/abortion/\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"contextual_link\"\u003eabortion\u003c/a\u003e access, heading into next months midterm elections.","type":"text","originalIdx":35},{"_id":"CYCKUQHN25B2JO6PE5UGVJ3HGQ","additional_properties":{},"content":"In interviews, federal and state officials lamented, for instance, how they failed to proactively explain a planned vote by CDC advisers last week to add coronavirus vaccinations to the agencys recommended immunization schedules for children, calling it a missed opportunity. Conservatives and Fox News personalities twisted the advisory panels vote into \u003ca href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/health/2022/10/19/covid-vaccines-children-cdc-disinformation/\" target=_blank\u003efalse claims\u003c/a\u003e that schools would immediately mandate that children receive the shots.","type":"text","originalIdx":36},{"_id":"X6SAJLTYEBE6PPGDMNAV7IBM34","additional_properties":{},"content":"Resneck, the AMAs president, said misinformation about covid and vaccines is being driven by a small number of people whose messages are amplified by social media. readabilityObject.title: Biden officials worry pandemic exhaustion could lead to bad covid winter
readabilityObject.content:
Amid projections that tens of thousands of Americans could die needlessly this winter if they dont get free coronavirus vaccine shots or treatments, White House Chief of Staff Ron Klain summoned health officials to a meeting last week with an urgent question: What can we do to prevent this?

What emerged from that session was a fall playbook to combat the virus that was timed to President Biden receiving an updated coronavirus vaccination shot (his fifth dose overall) on Tuesday, according to four people who spoke on the condition of anonymity because they were not authorized to comment. The steps include enlisting Walgreens, DoorDash and Uber to provide free delivery of antiviral prescriptions, and focusing on persuading vulnerable Americans, including seniors, to get vaccinations and booster shots.

As a country we have a choice to make, Biden said, before rolling up his left shirt sleeve to get the new shot. If we repeat the mistakes of past winters, he warned, we will see more infections, more hospitalizations, more loved ones getting sick, even dying, from the virus. Or can we have a much better winter, if we use all, all the tools we have available to us now, including reformulated booster shots and antiviral pills, such as Paxlovid.

The administration also is encouraging businesses to set up vaccination clinics, offer paid time off for workers to get shots, and improve their indoor air quality moves that officials and outside experts acknowledge recycle prior tactics rather than representing a new strategy and may not be enough to forestall many deaths.

Entering the nations third coronavirus winter, the United States appears to be in a far better position than it was during the past two: Treatments and booster shots are widely available, and most Americans have some protection against the viruss worst consequences, as a result of vaccinations, prior infections or both. As schools and businesses have reopened, a CNN poll released this month found that 55 percent of respondents approve of Bidens coronavirus response, versus just 36 percent who approve of his handling of the economy.

But health officials privately worry about limited funds, worn-out front-line health workers and the dwindling receptivity of many Americans to covid precautions. Polls show that many people are apathetic or confused about the need to get further vaccinations, opposed to resuming mask mandates and eager to put the pandemic behind them.

Approval of agencies like the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has fallen by about one-third since the start of the pandemic, according to a recent Pew Research poll, with the most significant criticism from Republicans who are disproportionately likely to be unvaccinated. Just 6 percent of eligible Americans have received an updated booster shot, according to federal data.

Nearly three years into a seemingly unending virus fight, local and national officials are weary, too, and said in interviews that theyve effectively exhausted tactics to reach vaccine holdouts and are pivoting to protect the most vulnerable Americans, such as seniors and people with immune-system conditions. Meanwhile, resurgent flu and other respiratory viruses are crowding hospitals, heaping more pressure on employees coping with persistent workforce shortages.

One of the top officials in Klains meeting CDC Director Rochelle Walensky, who joined remotely from Germany would soon test positive, scarcely a month after receiving an updated booster shot, underscoring the limits of vaccines to prevent infections from the evolving virus, although studies show they protect against severe covid infections and death.

Were in a very challenging phase, to be very honest. I know most folks dont want to hear that, said Syra Madad, an epidemiologist who helps oversee pandemic response for NYC Health and Hospitals, the nations largest municipal health-care system. Barely anybody is masking. We have very low vaccination rates for the updated boosters, as well as generally waning immunity. And to top it all off, we have these highly immune-evasive subvariants that are circulating.

Madad credited administration officials efforts to continue warning about the virus but said nearly two years of pandemic response had taken its toll on them, as well as on the American public.

They are working off of fumes, she said.

The biggest unknown heading into the winter is a shape-shifting virus that is becoming more adept at evading immunity. At this point a year ago, the virus variant that became omicron had not been identified but by Christmas 2021, it had caused tens of millions of infections, and by January 2022, it led to some of the highest death rates of the pandemic. Scientists say omicron variant descendants such as B.Q.1.1 and XBB could soon render useless treatments such as Evusheld, a therapy used to prevent illness in immunocompromised people.

If we hit a bad outcome [again], I think were going to be shocked again into action, while just realizing how much we let our guard down, said J. Stephen Morrison, who oversees global health policy at the Center for Strategic and International Studies. He also pointed to struggles to deal with other recent outbreaks, such as monkeypox cases in the United States and Europe, and Ebola cases in Uganda, saying sluggish efforts to conduct contact tracing and implement protections show persistent cracks in the global health response. Its just depressing that three years into this pandemic, were in such a weak position so much weaker than we should have been and so much weaker than we were when we started, Morrison said.

The path could get tougher next year. Republicans are expected to win one or both chambers of Congress, further clouding the prospects of a long-stalled virus funding package of more than $20 billion sought by the White House. The Biden administration also plans to phase out government purchases of vaccines and other treatments in 2023, pushing the cost to patients and insurers and potentially hindering uptake.

About 360 deaths per day are still linked to covid, and over the course of the winter, the administration is bracing for 30,000 to 70,000 additional casualties despite public health experts insistence that most of those deaths can be avoided with vaccinations and antiviral treatments.

This year, nearly every death is preventable. Let me say it again: Nearly every death is preventable, Biden said Tuesday.

Regional disparities have also emerged, with persistent gaps in vaccinations between Democrats and Republicans and higher death rates as a result.

I worry about future responses because of how political weve made this thing, said Alex Jahangir, a Vanderbilt Health trauma surgeon who led Nashvilles coronavirus task force for two years. Were at a place where most people know what to do to keep themselves from being super sick and dying. The problem especially in the Southeast is, we choose not to do it.

Seeking to ramp up awareness of those tools, Health and Human Services Secretary Xavier Becerra is attending vaccination events in Texas and California this week, and his agency is launching ads targeting rural, Black and Latino populations.

AARP, an advocacy group for seniors, held a telephone town hall last week during which White House coronavirus coordinator Ashish Jha fielded questions, such as how to gather safely for Thanksgiving, from more than 35,000 attendees. AARP is also set to send its monthly magazine to its nearly 38 million members with a cover story on how seniors can stay healthy this winter by accessing coronavirus treatments, tests and vaccines.

Im both worried and optimistic about the winter, said Debra Whitman, AARPs chief public policy officer, saying her organization is focused on boosting vaccination rates among older adults. She pointed to high-risk settings such as nursing homes, where just 43 percent of employees and 55 percent of residents were up-to-date on their vaccinations, according to AARPs latest scorecard. These are preventable deaths, in places where far too many people have died already, she said.

The Biden administration has also enlisted health-care providers, through groups such as the American Medical Association and the American Association of Nurse Practitioners, to encourage their patients to get vaccinated, part of a broader push toward shots in doctors offices and clinics, rather than in mass vaccination sites

We dont have a crystal ball but there are some concerning signs about upticks [in cases] and some new variants, said AMA President Jack Resneck Jr., who joined about a dozen clinical leaders at the White House last week. And so the American Medical Association and physicians broadly are really encouraging Americans to get their updated boosters because we really want to reduce both hospitalizations and deaths this winter.

Some outside experts have said the administrations efforts are coming too late, pointing to moments when Biden or his deputies seemed to put the virus behind them with the president declaring on television last month that the pandemic is over, for instance.

Ceclia Tomori, director of global public health and community health at Johns Hopkins School of Nursing, said Biden officials had increasingly turned their pandemic strategy into individual choices, rather than taking responsibility for the nations collective response.

When you make a rhetorical choice like the pandemic of the unvaccinated, youre really shifting blame, Tomori said. She argued that the phrase, which was first uttered by Walensky and repeated by Biden and other officials, needlessly alienated Americans who had yet to get vaccinated. Republicans also mocked the statement after the virus evolved to the point that vaccines failed to prevent infections among vaccinated people.

Several of Bidens former advisers said the president could do more to deliver on his campaign pledge to improve the nations public health infrastructure.

We need to assess the opportunities squandered or missed in the Covid pandemic and seize them now, four former Biden coronavirus advisers wrote in an op-ed in the New York Times last week. The column blamed Congress for not authorizing billions of dollars for such public health efforts and the administration for failing to adopt relatively low-cost interventions, such as standardizing how wastewater is sampled to detect covid and other viruses, or issuing national air quality standards that could lead to safer restaurants, businesses and schools.

We cant let this moment pass with so few structural, substantive, institutional improvements. It would be a terrible tragedy, said Ezekiel Emanuel, a University of Pennsylvania bioethicist and one of the co-authors. Because a lot of people will die the next time around. We dont know when exactly thats going to be, but its going to be.

Public health experts acknowledge that the messaging climate is difficult, partly because of public exhaustion with covid, but also because Democrats have sought to amplify other messages, such as abortion access, heading into next months midterm elections.

In interviews, federal and state officials lamented, for instance, how they failed to proactively explain a planned vote by CDC advisers last week to add coronavirus vaccinations to the agencys recommended immunization schedules for children, calling it a missed opportunity. Conservatives and Fox News personalities twisted the advisory panels vote into false claims that schools would immediately mandate that children receive the shots.

Resneck, the AMAs president, said misinformation about covid and vaccines is being driven by a small number of people whose messages are amplified by social media. It has taken an enormous amount of effort for physicians to push back against that disinformation thats out there, he added.

The White House is also bracing for the departure of one of its top messengers, Anthony S. Fauci, the governments lead infectious-disease expert and Bidens chief medical adviser, who has said he will step down before the years end.

Faucis exit could align with other changes across the health team. Jeff Zients and Natalie Quillian, who led Bidens coronavirus response before stepping down this spring, have returned to the White House to oversee potential personnel changes after the midterms, Axios first reported.

The White Houses persistent frustrations with Becerra, driven by concerns about his lack of experience in front-line public health and in running a sprawling federal agency, prompted internal discussions about replacing the health secretary early this year. Administration officials also faulted Becerras team this summer for stumbles on monkeypox, which included delays in ramping up testing and delivering vaccine doses that had been ordered and paid for, according to six people with knowledge of the conversations who were not authorized to comment.

Becerras spokesperson, Sarah Lovenheim, rebutted assertions by some officials that the longtime California congressman and former state attorney general is planning to leave after the midterms to pursue political opportunities in California.

This is untrue. He would say hes not doing that today, tomorrow or next year, Lovenheim said in a statement. He looks forward to negotiating prescription drug costs, protecting reproductive rights, doubling down to strengthen mental and behavioral health, public health preparedness and more.

Administration officials have also discussed whether Walensky, who has faced criticism for the CDCs sometimes-confusing messages on the pandemic, would leave after the midterms, according to three people with knowledge of those deliberations who spoke on the condition of anonymity to discuss sensitive conversations. Unlike other positions, such as HHS secretary, the role of CDC director does not require Senate confirmation, making it easier for the administration to execute a job change.

A spokesperson for Walensky referred The Washington Post to her interview this month with CNNs Chris Wallace, in which the director touted her agency-reform plan, announced in August, and promised to stay on to oversee it. My work is not done, Walensky said.
readabilityObject.textContent: Amid projections that tens of thousands of Americans could die needlessly this winter if they dont get free coronavirus vaccine shots or treatments, White House Chief of Staff Ron Klain summoned health officials to a meeting last week with an urgent question: What can we do to prevent this?What emerged from that session was a fall playbook to combat the virus that was timed to President Biden receiving an updated coronavirus vaccination shot (his fifth dose overall) on Tuesday, according to four people who spoke on the condition of anonymity because they were not authorized to comment. The steps include enlisting Walgreens, DoorDash and Uber to provide free delivery of antiviral prescriptions, and focusing on persuading vulnerable Americans, including seniors, to get vaccinations and booster shots.As a country  we have a choice to make, Biden said, before rolling up his left shirt sleeve to get the new shot. If we repeat the mistakes of past winters, he warned, we will see more infections, more hospitalizations, more loved ones getting sick, even dying, from the virus. Or can we have a much better winter, if we use all, all the tools we have available to us now, including reformulated booster shots and antiviral pills, such as Paxlovid.The administration also is encouraging businesses to set up vaccination clinics, offer paid time off for workers to get shots, and improve their indoor air quality  moves that officials and outside experts acknowledge recycle prior tactics rather than representing a new strategy and may not be enough to forestall many deaths.Entering the nations third coronavirus winter, the United States appears to be in a far better position than it was during the past two: Treatments and booster shots are widely available, and most Americans have some protection against the viruss worst consequences, as a result of vaccinations, prior infections or both. As schools and businesses have reopened, a CNN poll released this month found that 55 percent of respondents approve of Bidens coronavirus response, versus just 36 percent who approve of his handling of the economy.But health officials privately worry about limited funds, worn-out front-line health workers and the dwindling receptivity of many Americans to covid precautions. Polls show that many people are apathetic or confused about the need to get further vaccinations, opposed to resuming mask mandates and eager to put the pandemic behind them.Approval of agencies like the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has fallen by about one-third since the start of the pandemic, according to a recent Pew Research poll, with the most significant criticism from Republicans who are disproportionately likely to be unvaccinated. Just 6 percent of eligible Americans have received an updated booster shot, according to federal data.Nearly three years into a seemingly unending virus fight, local and national officials are weary, too, and said in interviews that theyve effectively exhausted tactics to reach vaccine holdouts and are pivoting to protect the most vulnerable Americans, such as seniors and people with immune-system conditions. Meanwhile, resurgent flu and other respiratory viruses are crowding hospitals, heaping more pressure on employees coping with persistent workforce shortages.One of the top officials in Klains meeting  CDC Director Rochelle Walensky, who joined remotely from Germany  would soon test positive, scarcely a month after receiving an updated booster shot, underscoring the limits of vaccines to prevent infections from the evolving virus, although studies show they protect against severe covid infections and death.Were in a very challenging phase, to be very honest. I know most folks dont want to hear that, said Syra Madad, an epidemiologist who helps oversee pandemic response for NYC Health and Hospitals, the nations largest municipal health-care system. Barely anybody is masking. We have very low vaccination rates for the updated boosters, as well as generally waning immunity. And to top it all off, we have these highly immune-evasive subvariants that are circulating.Madad credited administration officials efforts to continue warning about the virus  but said nearly two years of pandemic response had taken its toll on them, as well as on the American public.They are working off of fumes, she said.The biggest unknown heading into the winter is a shape-shifting virus that is becoming more adept at evading immunity. At this point a year ago, the virus variant that became omicron had not been identified  but by Christmas 2021, it had caused tens of millions of infections, and by January 2022, it led to some of the highest death rates of the pandemic. Scientists say omicron variant descendants such as B.Q.1.1 and XBB could soon render useless treatments such as Evusheld, a therapy used to prevent illness in immunocompromised people.If we hit a bad outcome [again], I think were going to be shocked again into action, while just realizing how much we let our guard down, said J. Stephen Morrison, who oversees global health policy at the Center for Strategic and International Studies. He also pointed to struggles to deal with other recent outbreaks, such as monkeypox cases in the United States and Europe, and Ebola cases in Uganda, saying sluggish efforts to conduct contact tracing and implement protections show persistent cracks in the global health response. Its just depressing that three years into this pandemic, were in such a weak position  so much weaker than we should have been and so much weaker than we were when we started, Morrison said.The path could get tougher next year. Republicans are expected to win one or both chambers of Congress, further clouding the prospects of a long-stalled  virus funding package of more than $20 billion sought by the White House. The Biden administration also plans to phase out government purchases of vaccines and other treatments in 2023, pushing the cost to patients and insurers and potentially hindering uptake.About 360 deaths per day are still linked to covid, and over the course of the winter, the administration is bracing for 30,000 to 70,000 additional casualties despite public health experts insistence that most of those deaths can be avoided with vaccinations and antiviral treatments.This year, nearly every death is preventable. Let me say it again: Nearly every death is preventable, Biden said Tuesday.Regional disparities have also emerged, with persistent gaps in vaccinations between Democrats and Republicans and higher death rates as a result.I worry about future responses because of how political weve made this thing, said Alex Jahangir, a Vanderbilt Health trauma surgeon who led Nashvilles coronavirus task force for two years. Were at a place where most people know what to do to keep themselves from being super sick and dying. The problem  especially in the Southeast  is, we choose not to do it.Seeking to ramp up awareness of those tools, Health and Human Services Secretary Xavier Becerra is attending vaccination events in Texas and California this week, and his agency is launching ads targeting rural, Black and Latino populations.AARP, an advocacy group for seniors, held a telephone town hall last week during which White House coronavirus coordinator Ashish Jha fielded questions, such as how to gather safely for Thanksgiving, from more than 35,000 attendees. AARP is also set to send its monthly magazine to its nearly 38 million members with a cover story on how seniors can stay healthy this winter by accessing coronavirus treatments, tests and vaccines.Im both worried and optimistic about the winter, said Debra Whitman, AARPs chief public policy officer, saying her organization is focused on boosting vaccination rates among older adults. She pointed to high-risk settings such as nursing homes, where just 43 percent of employees and 55 percent of residents were up-to-date on their vaccinations, according to AARPs latest scorecard. These are preventable deaths, in places where far too many people have died already, she said.The Biden administration has also enlisted health-care providers, through groups such as the American Medical Association and the American Association of Nurse Practitioners, to encourage their patients to get vaccinated, part of a broader push toward shots in doctors offices and clinics, rather than in mass vaccination sitesWe dont have a crystal ball  but there are some concerning signs about upticks [in cases] and some new variants, said AMA President Jack Resneck Jr., who joined about a dozen clinical leaders at the White House last week. And so the American Medical Association and physicians broadly are really encouraging Americans to get their updated boosters because we really want to reduce both hospitalizations and deaths this winter.Some outside experts have said the administrations efforts are coming too late, pointing to moments when Biden or his deputies seemed to put the virus behind them  with the president declaring on television last month that the pandemic is over, for instance.Ceclia Tomori, director of global public health and community health at Johns Hopkins School of Nursing, said Biden officials had increasingly turned their pandemic strategy into individual choices, rather than taking responsibility for the nations collective response.When you make a rhetorical choice like the pandemic of the unvaccinated, youre really shifting blame, Tomori said. She argued that the phrase, which was first uttered by Walensky and repeated by Biden and other officials, needlessly alienated Americans who had yet to get vaccinated. Republicans also mocked the statement after the virus evolved to the point that vaccines failed to prevent  infections among vaccinated people.Several of Bidens former advisers said the president could do more to deliver on his campaign pledge to improve the nations public health infrastructure.We need to assess the opportunities squandered or missed in the Covid pandemic and seize them now, four former Biden coronavirus advisers wrote in an op-ed in the New York Times last week. The column blamed Congress for not authorizing billions of dollars for such public health efforts and the administration for failing to adopt relatively low-cost interventions, such as standardizing how wastewater is sampled to detect covid and other viruses, or issuing national air quality standards that could lead to safer restaurants, businesses and schools.We cant let this moment pass with so few structural, substantive, institutional improvements. It would be a terrible tragedy, said Ezekiel Emanuel, a University of Pennsylvania bioethicist and one of the co-authors. Because a lot of people will die the next time around.
